Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing Multicomponent Vaporization of Petroleum-Biofuel Drops at High-Pressure Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1332238
Kong
This project conducts vaporization experiments and modeling of petroleum and biofuel droplets. The fuels to be studied include both traditional petroleum-biofuel blends and novel biofuels, including pyrolysis oil, green diesel, hydrotreated diesel, and various aviation biofuels. Liquid biofuels are usually blended with petroleum fuels; their clean and efficient combustion is of vast interest in terms of economy and environmental impacts. One of the major obstacles to their widespread application arises from their unusual vaporization characteristics, which have a determining effect on mixture distribution and combustion. The intellectual merit of this proposal is the experimental characterization, and creation, of predictive models for petroleum-biofuel vaporization under high-pressure and high-temperature conditions. Such experimental data are very rare and can be used by the research community for model validation, thus making significant impacts. This work will address several critical fundamental aspects of droplet vaporization, including effects of biofuel components, effects of high pressure on droplet lifetime, relative importance of latent heat and boiling point on vaporization, the role of internal mixing in the liquid phase, and micro-explosion of pyrolysis oil drops. The broader impact of this project is the promotion of bio-renewable energy through research and education. The proposed activities include the research training of K-12 science teachers, who can then serve to inspire their students, and a plan to foster long-term relationships and regular interactions between the PI and the visiting teachers. The proposed outreach activities also include the visits by undergraduate students to K-12 students in regional high-need school districts, demonstrating racing vehicles using biofuels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has resulted in numerical modeling tools and experimental datasets which will provide new capabilities in the design, modeling, and optimization of more efficient combustion systems. The models and experimental data for validation are crucial to the accurate prediction of what takes place when fuel is injected in combustors and engines. Current and future combustion systems target a wide range of operating conditions (high pressure, a range of temperatures), and a wide range of fuels. Capturing the relevant physics is necessary to predict the behavior of conventional petroleum-derived fuels (gasoline, diesel) as well as bio-derived fuels and mixtures (bio-diesel, pyrolysis oil, ethanol-blended). This project has resulted in the development and validation of predictive models which will aid in the prediction of performance with alternative fuel systems, and in the design of high-efficiency, more fuel-flexible combustion systems.

A computational model based on a smoothed particle hydrodynamic (SPH) method was developed and validated for the prediction of vaporizing liquid fuels. The model captures heat and mass transport effects, including the preferential vaporization of different fuel components. This predictive computational model can be used to simulate multiphase combustion sprays, while capturing the important physical phenomena taking place during drop vaporization.

Experimental measurements of single-component, bi-component, and multi-component fuels have provided validation data for engine-relevant conditions. These data consist of drop vaporization rates over a range of relevant temperatures and fuel mixtures, serving as a data set for validation of vaporization models. In addition, experimental studies have examined the role of fuel composition on the vaporization and drop physics at the surface of a hot wall. The interaction between drops and walls is commonplace in many combustors, and these studies have clearly identified the outcomes of multicomponent liquid drops hitting walls.

The project has provided opportunities to engage K-12 schools through a successful summer training internship with an educator, providing a link between the scientific laboratory studies and secondary education classrooms. A number of undergraduate and graduate students have been integral to the research efforts, and they have presented results at a number of local research symposia scientific meetings. These opportunities have provided scientific training as they progress in engineering and scientific careers.
